comments.timestamp: In high school, I attended a Presidential Classroom for Young Americans. It gave you chance for a week to

comments.text:
visit all the different branches of the federal government and see how everything works. It included a visit
to the offices of the CIA. We went at night, was not able to take a tape recorder, camera, pen or paper into
the building. During that week the news was reporting that the CIA had tried to kill Castro. The man who
was running our session at the CIA stood at the front of the auditorium where we were and stated “yes, the
CIA had multiple plans to try and kill Castro”. The entire room gasped. It is one thing for the news to report
this info and another to be in that room and have their representative admit it.

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: For me, it all comes down to Oswald. If he was the lone assassin as the government says, a nut who was a

comments.text:
wacko, lunatic, crackpot, then Oswald would have wanted the whole world to know why he did it. However,
he denied it the whole time while he had plenty of opportunity to spill the beans for what he was said to
have done. He was escorted multiple times through the Dallas PD hallways full of reporters and cameras.
Think about that: Sirhan wanted everyone to know why he shot Bobby.  Oswald never said anything other
than he didn't do it. Also, he was held and interrogated from Friday afternoon until Sunday morning when
he was shot. Where are the recordings from the relentless interrogations that were done? Where are the
written notes and transcripts? Come on! It doesn't add up

use that cover to take the shots from their designated spots. There was always at least 2 shooters, as
seen in the plans for the Chicago hit.

comments.timestamp: Johnny I'm gonna be honest I think you missed a HUGE part of this equation: the economic ramifications.

comments.text:
We can argue about who would win in a military confrontation between the US and China until hell freezes
over, but the economic ramifications for China if they chose to invade Taiwan tomorrow would be
DISASTROUS. I'm talking full-scale collapse of their entire economy. The reason? China relies on
international trade for its economy to function. It is a manufacturing hub that produces goods for the
entire world. And guess who their biggest trading partner is: THE UNITED STATES! China has an
enormous trade surplus with the United States (meaning we buy more from them then they do from us). If
that line of trade evaporated overnight, it would absolutely decimate the Chinese economy. It would also
have a huge negative impact on the United States, but certainly not to the same extent as China. The
negative economic ramifications of a Chinese invasion of Taiwan alone are enough for China to table the
idea for the foreseeable future. There are efforts underway in China to wean itself off of i

comments.timestamp: I had a professor, his name gave away that he was Bosnian so he was put into a labor camp cutting down

comments.text:
trees mostly. After some time he was let go. Later he was taken to another labor camp and forced to dig
trenches, he acted as a guard and escaped with a fake ID and lived in Belgrade until the war ended. He
told us “And that was my first performance” and that that performance was the start for his love of acting,
and the arts.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: As a Bosnian, who witnessed firsthand and survived these events, I can say that in this rather short video,

comments.text: Johnny , you  painted the picture pretty well. It brings tears to my eyes. Thanks
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: As a young child, I spent the entire duration of the war in Bosnia. My mother, who was in her early twenties

comments.text:
at the time, and I were constantly on the move, seeking shelter from the relentless bombings. I vividly
recall waiting in line for aid from the Red Cross and having to flee from their bombs.
One night, my father, who was also in his twenties and deployed on the front line, returned to us. However,
my mother did not recognize him at first due to the hardships we had endured. Despite being a Bosniak,
my father's best friends were a Serb and a Croat, which further emphasizes the tragic divide that the war
had created.
The aftermath of the war was also challenging for us. Food shortages were rampant, and my father's
salary was paid in one bag of groceries per month instead of money. To supplement our food supply, we
went on frequent fishing trips to a nearby river. These fishing trips are among the few memories from that
time that I recall with a smile.

My mom was an exchange student in the US when the war broke out, overnight her passport was
worthless and at 18 she was a war refugee in the United States. It’s remarkable how I get emotional just
by watching this video - even though I wasn’t even alive at the time - the sadness, it’s cross generational -
that’s the real impact of war.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: A lot Bosnians moved to St. Louis MO cause of this war. I hate the reason they moved here, but I love their

comments.text:
community in the area. I've always worked with someone from Bosnia, they have always been fantastic,
caring and loving people. Their stories have broken my heart countless times.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: hey next week's video is one of my favorites I've ever made and it's live right now (I publish all my videos a

comments.text:
week early on Nebula). It's about how we mapped Antarctica. Go check it out: https://nebula.
tv/videos/johnnyharris-mapping-antarctica-how-humans-did-the-impossible
PS: a portion of you Nebula subscription goes directly to supporting us to make more videos!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: You forgot to mention Kosovo, you put Kosovo in the map with Serbia that's supa dupa wrong. Kosovo has

comments.text: it own independence, do your research better next time!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: As a Bosnian and someone who survived this horrible war I thank you from the bottom of my heart for this

comments.text: episode ❤ 💙💛 . P .s. Fun fact: Bosnia is often called The Heart Shaped Land.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Great video. I can highly recommend traveling to Bosnia. It offers a great combination of culture, nature

comments.text:
and amazing food. And all of it very affordable. Check out Sarajevo, Mostar, Blagaj, Stolac, Bijeljina,
Trebinje, Travnik and Visegrad - they are all incredibly beautiful places.
But Bosnia doesn't need pity. It needs tourists. That's how Croatia recovered so quickly after the war.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Next to my apartment in Germany, there is a small pub. - Owner is Albanian, Customers are Croats,

comments.text:
Serbian, Bosnian, Greek and Turkish. We all live in peace, we all celebrate together. They have left the
battles of their fathers at home and decided to finally start again with love and joy for their shared food,
often the language and culture.  I am amazed every single day I pass this pub. It's called Arians Pub
(named after the owners son Arian) and it is in Hamburg. The most amazing gathering of Balkan states.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I'm Congolese, but I have a few ex-Yougoslavian friends (Bosnia, Serbie and Croatia), what my Bosnian

comments.text:
friends (and parents) told me about that war was horrific. It's strange how people who could live with each
other, look a like, ear the same food...and still be able to kill each other.
Fortunately, the war is over, but both side lost so much for...what?
I hope to visit Bosnia one day, as I have met great people from that country.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: This is a topic that is hard to put into a 15min video. It is very nuanced and complicated. I'm from one of

comments.text:
the "safe zones", the town of Gorazde. The stuff my parents and my siblings went through is
unimaginable. My fathers first wife was a Bosnian Serb, and she died from Serb shell right in front of my
dad. Maybe I wouldn't have been born if there wasn't this war, but I would still take not being born over
monstrosities that happened during that time and in my hometown. Sad part is, this country will probably
never heal and go forward from this war. We are still stuck in it. We are still stuck 30 years in the past.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I have a buddy who was a Delta operator. He went all over, Iraq, Mogadishu, and he said the worst things

comments.text: he saw, the most inhumane things,  was during this conflict.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: The UN's "protection" of Srebrenica is one of the biggest pieces of incompetence I have ever heard of.

comments.text: Absolutely infuriating.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: When I was in high school we were tasked with writing about “forgotten wars/ war crimes.” I had just

comments.text:
rewatched the movie Behind Enemy Lines which I would say loosely covers the bloodily conflict. After
watching the film I remembered my assignment and decided it was time to learn more about it. Needless
to say just after finishing up my report to the class there was a noticeable thickness in the air and the
class was awfully quiet. Most of my classmates just covered the basic facts in their assignments while I
went down a rabbit hole of the worst parts of humanity. I was quite depressed after it was all done, I think
we all were and none of us ever lived it.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I'm from Sarajevo and I was a part of the war there. You can't put into words what happened. The fact that

comments.text:
the city was blockaded in 1425, that thousands of children died, that the sports fields where I played
football as a boy were converted into cemeteries says it all.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: 60% of my family was killed during this war. I could have grown up with Cousins, uncles and aunts.

comments.text:
Saddest part is, the country and the people in it cannot recover properly due to the corrupt politics and
nationalism. Thank you for this video, bringing some attention back to this beautiful country!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: As a former history teacher, I appreciate so much the way you research and present this information.

comments.text:
Does it ever feel heavy in your heart as you report on the horrors of war and the devastation we visit on
each other?
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Being in the military myself, I know a lot of old dogs that consider Bosnia a one way ticket to PTSD.  Thats

comments.text:
basically the only thing everyone got from that tour.  Watching human beings being slaughtered and not
being able to do anything about it
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I was a child during the war. My dad was put in a concentration camp, Manjaca. We were forced to flee

comments.text:
our town, which was and still is predominantly Serbian. I am Muslim and have no hate towards anyone
and don’t wish the experience of a war to anyone. However, I am deeply disappointed and saddened by
the world’s silence as so many heinous crimes were committed against so many innocent people.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: My family are Croatians from Sarajevo. They lived near the Željo stadium. Gladly, my mother and

comments.text:
grandparents were able to leave right before the siege started because my grandfather saw it coming. My
stepfather wasn't so lucky. He lived through the entire siege, where he lost his father to a granade that
also hit him. Almost half of my family experienced the siege first hand. And that's just one of so many
affected places. I was born post-war in Germany, and I think it's so important to make the public more
aware of all the things that happened in this region because almost nobody knows anything about it
outside ex-yu countries. I appreciate this video a lot!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I remember in middle school a third of my class was made up of kids from former Yugoslavia. All of them

comments.text:
had different ethnic backgrounds but they ended up forming a comradeship and became good friends
because they all hated the war in general. None of them blamed anyone except the rich classes making
life miserable for everyone else. I learned a lot of Serbian/Croatian swearing while at that school.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: My wife and I just drove through this area last week from Greece, through Albania, Montenegro, Bosnia

comments.text:
and Herzegovina, Croatia, and Slovenia. We were googling along the way to try to understand more about
this region, because it's extremely complicated. Growing up in Norway I remember the news in the early
90's about Sarajevo and Bosnia, but we were never told the greater extent of the conflicts in the Balkans.
Thanks for helping to shed light on this.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: This was a very good overview of what was an extremely complex conflict. But it seems bizarre to think

comments.text:
that this is a forgotten war. The collapse of Yugoslavia and the war in Croatia and Bosnia defined the first
half of the 1990s. But I’m now getting students who weren’t born when 9/11 happened. I find it fascinating
how particular events are ‘remembered’ across generations and others aren’t.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: My father served in the 90s in Bosnia with the Canadian forces. He’s  ruined mentally now mostly because

comments.text: of what he had seen and done over there
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I visited Bosnia last summer and really loved the place and its vibes!! It was really disturbing to see the

comments.text:
remaining physical damages throughout the old buildings and to know what these people had been
through, i deeply relate to bosnians as we experienced almost the same story in Syria! But the difference is
that our wound is still bleeding and the criminal is wandering around.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: My girlfriend is Bosnian. Did not learn about the Bosnian genocide until I got to know her and her family. I

comments.text:
was able to relate to her mothers struggle as a Syrian. An insane let down by the whole world. Thank you
for making this episode
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I had a teacher who served as an UN peacekeeper and the stories he told us were chilling

comments.text:
neighbour completely ignores you and wants to kill you"
People now are like"now it's all good we alle like each other now" no it's not, the hate within the people
who experienced that will never go away.
It's trauma, war brings nothing but trauma.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: As a Bosnian, I can only say: Thank You, Johnny, for sharing and educating the world about the Bosnian

comments.text:
War.
Many people still deny the facts you showed (and many others too) and the biggest problem by far is that
deniers are raising deniers which is harming the country and the entire region.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I almost died twice because there were not enough doctors to save me in Rijeka, Croatia (doctors went to

comments.text:
Bosnia to save lives), where I was hospitalized because my appendix spilled during a seaside holiday in
August 1995. After a month, my mother fought to have me transferred to Ljubljana in our country Slovenia,
and they barely wrote me a discharge paper because they thought I was going to die during the
ambulance transport. I stayed in Ljubljana for another month, my weight was half off and I was left with a
large scar running vertically down the right side of my entire abdomen. Compared to that and what
happened in Bosnia it's not even remotely the same, because worse stories have been written on the other
side of the border. But I am glad that I survived and that makes me appreciate my life even more.
I love watching your videos and your approach to how you tell a story, you always choose a juicy subject
for which I always think to myself how blindfolded we are. Thank you for your contribution to our
community!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: as being bosnian, this war should be taught more in school. Honestly, its just completely slept on

comments.text:
me about how much he regrets all the stuff they did and wishe it never happened because before the war
them and the Serbs and Bosnians lived together in peace. He’s such a nice man but when you see him you
can always tell there’s like a side of him that will forever be sad which makes me feel bad
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I went to secondary school in Hong Kong in the early 2000s with a Bosnian girl whose family endured this

comments.text:
war.  She would appear visibly shaken when she told us her personal stories of the war.  She was often
moody.  She would recoil whenever someone touched her, and in hindsight I now realise that she was
suffering from PTSD.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Part of my family lived all the time in Sarajevo during the war. There were mixed marriages. My Croatian

comments.text:
cousin was married to a Serb and on the Serbian side of Sarajevo. Her brother (Croat) was on the
Bosnian/Croat side.  Both had to shoot and did not know if they were shooting at their own family at the
time or not.  Yugoslavia was such a cool country and to this day I can't really explain how something like
this could happen.  I fled to Germany in 1991 when I was 14 years old.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: First I heard about the war when I was a young interpreter during a UN mission. Bosnian women were

comments.text:
telling the stories of sexual violence they suffered at the hand of soldiers and some were in front of their
children. There were rape camps for women. I was not able to sleep for several days after hearing about
the details of such atrocities. My heart goes out to all the women who suffered such violation and
protected their children and went on to look for their men after the war. More people should learn about
this war as it confirms how ethnically motivated conflicts arise and tear apart diverse societies.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I’m a survivor of this war and I also lost two uncles during the conflict and it’s amazing how useless UN is

comments.text:
and was allowing thousands of people to be murdered. The world never seems to learn lessons and
change foreign policy.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: This is good basic coverage of the war, which was quite more complicated than it is explained here. I say

comments.text:
it as a bosnian girl born during the war, and the one who's lived here her whole life. I strongly suggest for
everyone to find more documentaries which are longer and go in detail more than this video.
Also Johnny, thanks for covering a story about my country and if you ever want to visit to see how people
live here 30 years later, I'll glady assist you with any information you need ( as an international relations
and diplomacy student )
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Having just visited Bosnia for the first time and seeing the scars of this war still visible all over the country,

comments.text:
this video was very informative. I must also say that Bosnia is one of the most beautiful countries I have
visited as well as the people being some of the most amazing, hospitable and friendliest that I have come
across. I can highly recommend it!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: If you're interested in learning more I definitely suggest watching "The Death of Yugoslavia". It was made

comments.text:
by the BBC around the mid-90s so they were able to interview all of the big players in the conflicts. It is
such a good series.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: When I visited Bosnia with my family, my dad showed me a vhs tape taken on an old camcorder. The video

comments.timestamp: We lived in Switzerland for 16 years. There was a bunker in the apartment buildings we lived in and in the

comments.text:
house we lived in. The bunker in the house was inspected and tested about every 4-5 years and there was
a signed sheet for completed and passed testing on the inside of the door, for every test since the house
was built.  If you built a home without a bunker, you had to pay your local municipality for the right to
space in the municipality's general bunker... they all have one.
The bunkers are NOT just for protection from war - "traditional" or nuclear - they are also for protection
from nuclear fallout in case one of many nuclear power plants goes kaboom. Because of the air filtering
system, they also provide safety in case of a chemical tanker accident and other things that can
contaminate the air where people live. Also, they would provide safe shelter in cases of extreme weather
or run-away fires.... and, probably, the whole house falling down on top of them.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: In 2012 my wife and I were on a train headed north from Geneva. I was looking out across open fields up

comments.text:
ahead of the train when I spotted what looked like maybe an F-16 taxi out onto what looked like a large
food producing field. I watched as the aircraft took off, then spotted another one taxiing out from an earth-
covered bunker, and a third before I lost sight of them. I was amazed and seriously impressed.

comments.timestamp: As a former officer in the Swiss army, I really enjoyed this, and wish you could see some of the stuff we

comments.text:
have, like underground airbases complete with fighter jets hanging in the ceiling, maintenence tunnels, the
insane fire suppression systems, and, as you showed it, the usual fortified maching gun position at the
end of a tunnel.
Not used anymore nowadays and mostly cold war relics, but that would nevertheless make any insane
James Bond villain hideout look like an amateurish Disneyland prop. Anyway, thanks for this, great work
and hope you enjoyed Switzerland. 😉😘

comments.timestamp: From a Swiss perspective... this is incredibly well researched for Youtube-video standards. You talked to

comments.text:
different people, you managed to catch the essence of the topic, and you also shed a light on different
political views and aspects. So often in internet-discussions you will only hear one side of the medal. E.g.
when looking for the reason why Germany didn't attack us in WW2, where some people will say it was
entirely due to the bunkers, and others will claim it was only because of the banks. You said it correctly, it
was most probably both and an elaborate risk vs reward analysis. Same goes for the neutrality topic that
was big in 2022 due to the Ukraine war. I am very much pro sanctions, because in my view neutrality does
not mean inactivity. A judge or a referee is expected to be neutral, but sanctioning is part of their job by
definition. However, I thought you shed light on both sides of the argument in an adequate way.
Discussions and debates are a huge part of Swiss  direct democracy. In the more recent years, certain
groups and parties tried to underminde that by using more em

comments.timestamp: To me, the main difference between NFTs and other non fungible things is an NFT have no real added

comments.text:
value.
You can look Mona Lisa on the internet. It's fungible, therefore it has very little value (in this case, none).
Or you can pay a ticket to go see it an experience the real thing. Added value = more expensive. Or you
coud buy it (if it was for sale), and then you could experience it every day. More added value = way more
expensive.
It's a pretty basic economic principle that people buying NFTs are forgetting. If it's more expensive, it's
because it has more value. Sure, for a lot of things, it's 1) subjective and 2) there is a part of perceived
value. But only a part. There is some real added value to possessing or experiencing the thing.
Possessing Nyan Cat's NFT brings no more value than just watching it on the internet for free.
That being said, people do whatever they want with their money. To me it's just foolish but hey 󰤇

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: One thing about NFTs that's rarely explained well is that NFT's are essentially a reciept of ownership. In

comments.text:
other words, if you buy a jpeg as an NFT, you don't own that jpeg. What you own is a public receipt
indicating ownership of the jpeg, and a link to that image. You own metadata. The image itself is NOT
hosted on the blockchain. Because of this, while nobody can change the ledger indicating that you own
the jpeg, somebody CAN change the image itself, or simply erase it. If the domain that's hosting the link
goes offline, or if the owner of the domain changes the image, as the owner of the NFT, there's nothing
you can do about it. Blockchain is impressive technology, but NFTs are a scam. Don't buy the hype.

fly for more than a matter of minutes at the reported velocities we could even reach, without running out
of fuel. If any of our near-peer adversaries had this tech, they would be taking over whatever they wished
to take over- there would be no reason not to. Yet China and Russia (and us) all tiptoe around, concerned
about how the other two will respond.

comments.timestamp: So I'm a hairdresser - in you are kinda right, but not 100%. Shampoos with Sodium Lauryl sulphates (SLS)

comments.text:
will strip out the natural oils, as it is basically a detergent. Yes it causes your scalp to become dry ....
because it has stripped your natural oils. Your sebaceous glands become dehydrated and to deal with it -
produce more oils.  So that creates a cycle which isn't healthy for your scalp or hair. I wash my hair every 7
to 10 days ... I use a shampoo, but without the SLS stuff, and recommend it to my customers because it
also will not strip out the colour they have paid me to apply ! Conditioners - well a shampoo will open up
the outer layer of your hair, and a conditioner closes it back, but with longer hair, it also helps add oils that
may be missing, due to the hairs age - and what we do to it. Not all contain silicones - and they are bad for
it. The 3 companies you mentioned - yup they have marketed to people and produced an empire from it ...
which is based on things that are not fundamentally always the case for people.
Toothpaste - you don't NEED it, to get your teeth clean,

comments.timestamp: Definitely it's a lie. In fact, most personal grooming habits we take for granted now weren't practiced until

comments.text:
the 1970's when Madison Ave. started bombarding us with ads for shampoo, soap, perfume, and shaving
products and convinced us that we had to shower every single day. A few years later, when our skin was
drying out from too much showering, they sold us moisturizers! You have to admit, they didn't miss a trick.
Each problem caused by the previous ad campaign was solved by another until we were buying hundreds
of products we didn't need and that we'd be better off without.

your hair too much or less is a lie, you should only wash your hair when you feel that there's too much oil

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: I grew up in India in the 90s. Shampoo was comparatively a new thing and quite expensive too.

comments.text:
Traditionally we never used shampoo to wash our hair but used a homemade powder called SHIKAKAI
that's made from gooseberry, fenugreek, rosemary and few other natural ingredients.
For centuries, South Indians have been using Shikakai powder mixed in water to wash hair. We usually oil
our hair (let it soak for a few hours) once a week and wash it with Shikakai right after. We don't usually
wash our hair everyday. And guess what? South Indians  are known for thick, strong and silky hair!
Times have changed now and very few Indians now follow these traditional methods including me, but it
clearly shows how we can healthy hair without using any chemicals and washing less!! I wish more people
knew about this.
Kudos to you Johnny Haris for figuring out what works best for you naturally! 👏

comments.timestamp: Growing up I shampood my hair everyday because I was taught that that's just what humans in the first

comments.text:
world do. My hair would always be overly dry or overly oily as a result. In my later teens I started
experimenting with shampoo'ing much less frequently, like every 4-6 days. Within a couple weeks my
scalp adjusted oil production and my hair seemed to be in better condition than when I was shampooing
every day. Now, I do it even less than that. I just shampoo when it actually feels dirty, which is once or
twice a month on average, and the quality of my hair is better now at age 39 than it was in my teens and
twenties.

00:30 like i was a couple of years ago who is questioning and wondering can have another perspective to lean on i'm not looking to get into debates or to talk about the history or the theology Time: 00:30 - 00:40 of the church i'll do that in future videos today all i want to do is tell you the story of how and why i left the mormon church 23rd of Time: 00:40 - 00:50 may 2009 Time: 00:50 - 01:00 i grew up mormon both my parents were at mormon or lds latter-day saints i grew up going to mormon youth camp i then eventually Time: 01:00 - 01:10 served a two-year mission in tijuana mexico where for two years i went around and spoke to people in spanish about the Time: 01:10 - 01:20 church and learned a lot learned to speak spanish fluently keris how you feel malicious Time: 01:20 - 01:30 i then went to the mormon university called brigham young university in provo utah where i graduated i went through all mormon rituals in the Time: 01:30 - 01:40 church and temple i worked in the temple as a volunteer for a time i was very very mormon and i believed it Time: 01:40 - 01:50 i believed deeply in the unique doctrine of the church of jesus christ of latter-day saints which is a christian organization unlike any other christian organization in its Time: 01:50 - 02:00 doctrine [Music] the story of how i decided to leave this really begins with the birth Time: 02:00 - 02:10 of my son [Music] isabel who also grew up mormon and i got Time: 02:10 - 02:20 married in the temple which is a huge mormon ritual it's a huge part of being in the church we got married in the temple we went back to byu together and a few weeks before we graduated from byu Time: 02:20 - 02:30 we had a baby or izzy had a baby i didn't have a baby she had a baby then we took finals and graduated like literally two weeks later Time: 02:30 - 02:40 here we are literally in our cap and gown with henry who is like two weeks old after we graduated we moved out to washington dc and that's when my Time: 02:40 - 02:50 wheels really started to turn i started to think you know i have a child now i have to decide how i raise this child and what i teach him about Time: 02:50 - 03:00 the world i think having henry really made me wonder and think about how i should Time: 03:00 - 03:10 teach him about the world i had grown up with this firm conviction of the lds doctrine and its beliefs about the world which are very specific Time: 03:10 - 03:20 and very peculiar and i really started to question is this what i want to teach my son and the answer initially was yes i want to teach him everything that i know about this Time: 03:20 - 03:30 faith because i really believed it so we're moving out to washington dc and i realized that if i'm going to teach this to my son i need to Time: 03:30 - 03:40 double down on my faith i need to go deeper than i ever have and really really establish a strong foundation and conviction around this doctrine i had one but i knew it needed to be Time: 03:40 - 03:50 stronger if i was going to teach my son this one of the things i loved about mormon doctrine at the time was that there was always a push to ask god if it was true Time: 03:50 - 04:00 not to trust any people or any organization but to like get on your knees and say god is this true is this is this church actually real is that all of the things that they say Time: 04:00 - 04:10 actually the real deal i had kind of taken advantage of that promise before but never really i had always been in a setting of Time: 04:10 - 04:20 pressure whether it was my home as a kid or my mission or byu in other words there was always an incentive to believe so i'd never really been in a situation Time: 04:20 - 04:30 where i could truly ask this question and not feel like there was some price to pay if i decided i didn't believe being in Time: 04:30 - 04:40 washington dc with my child out on my own in the workforce was my opportunity so i spent an entire year reading the book of mormon going to church i had a responsibility at church Time: 04:40 - 04:50 that i was putting a lot of work into and praying every morning and every night for some sort of conviction i said i am more earnest and sincere than i've ever Time: 04:50 - 05:00 been about this i'm willing to listen to any answer i just need an answer i spent a year doing this a year it's a long time and then i remember Time: 05:00 - 05:10 this day i was biking into washington dc um on a sunny like spring day and Time: 05:10 - 05:20 it just hit me in some really strong way that no this isn't working i've put in the years of asking and the Time: 05:20 - 05:30 effort towards making this work and it wasn't working this isn't true for me and like a switch Time: 05:30 - 05:40 it just so much came out of me and i quickly decided that i was done i don't think it was all Time: 05:40 - 05:50 at once i think i had been slowly moving in this direction for a long time but in a moment of clarity it clicked for me in a very satisfying and like very true Time: 05:50 - 06:00 way so is who is is he isabelle whatever you want to call her my wife it didn't click for her she was not on this journey that i was on Time: 06:00 - 06:10 and i came back and i told her i said i think i am done being mormon and i had always been the sort of more devout convicted mormon and she was just like Time: 06:10 - 06:20 what like you just like have decided to be out of the church and she she full on said like this this is gonna end our marriage like you can't just leave the church and Time: 06:20 - 06:30 i just told her i said this is where i stand and this is what i feel and i felt very strongly about it luckily soon enough izzy was on her own path of reconciling her thoughts about the Time: 06:30 - 06:40 church her qualms with the church and soon she would join me in this path towards leaving the church now i call it a path because that's Time: 06:40 - 06:50 exactly what it is leaving any orthodox religion is not easy there are layers and layers of psychological and cultural conditioning that you don't Time: 06:50 - 07:00 even realize is there until you start to peel it back so even though we started to leave the church we were still going to church every sunday which i don't really Time: 07:00 - 07:10 understand in retrospect all i can say is that like we were just that's what we did every sunday we went to church and there was some guilt if we didn't go to church and so we went to church but we slowly started to feel an Time: 07:10 - 07:20 emptiness towards it and over the course of six months we finally decided to stop going to church my behavior didn't change all of a Time: 07:20 - 07:30 sudden like i didn't leave the church so i could start drinking alcohol or coffee or smoking like that was not a part of the agenda for me i kind of just carried on exactly how i Time: 07:30 - 07:40 had always been except for now i looked around in the world and i didn't have a doctrinal theological framework to understand it which was at once exhilarating and Time: 07:40 - 07:50 horrifying at the same time my existential view had been so neatly packaged by the plan of salvation which is the key doctrinal Time: 07:50 - 08:00 framework within the mormon church and that was now gone i had no plan i had no framework to make sense of the world exhilarating but horrifying there was Time: 08:00 - 08:10 also a deep fear of the cultural and social repercussions of my decision most of my friends were still lds or Time: 08:10 - 08:20 mormon and of course my family was too so was izzy's and let me just try to give you a perspective on why this is such a big deal a quick primer on mormon theology is Time: 08:20 - 08:30 that our whole purpose in life is to come down here to earth to learn and to grow and to progress and to attain knowledge and to fulfill certain Time: 08:30 - 08:40 we call them covenants or rituals there are four of them that are really important to do while you're on earth baptism confirmation this hour-long Time: 08:40 - 08:50 ritual inside the temple and then called the endowment and then the ceiling or marriage if you can do those four things then Time: 08:50 - 09:00 you're in really good shape you have the knowledge necessary to go back and live in the top tier of heaven and yes in mormon theology there are multiple tiers of heaven Time: 09:00 - 09:10 if you're not able to get these rituals done while you're on earth no worries when you're in the next life people on earth can do all the rituals for you while when you're dead and then you can Time: 09:10 - 09:20 have those the chance to accept those rituals or those covenants when you're on the other side it's a huge deal i had gone through all Time: 09:20 - 09:30 of the rituals i had accepted all of those covenants which are very serious covenants you wear undergarments that are symbolic of those covenants that you've made Time: 09:30 - 09:40 people call them like secret underwear or whatever but it was just religious clothing that symbolizes your commitment to these doctrines and the beauty of all of this Time: 09:40 - 09:50 within mormon doctrine is if you do this and everyone in your family does this then all of you are sealed together in this never-ending chain of eternal Time: 09:50 - 10:00 family that is at the epicenter of mormon doctrines if you know mormons and you know that they are family centered it's because of this the whole doctrine is based on Time: 10:00 - 10:10 creating family units that are all tied into this this covenant these promises that bind you that seal you together for time and all eternity Time: 10:10 - 10:20 if you've accepted those covenants and then you leave you break away you reject those covenants you take off your garments you say i'm done with this Time: 10:20 - 10:30 that's a pretty big deal within the lds framework you are no longer able to be with your family in the celestial glory Time: 10:30 - 10:40 of the top tier of heaven so if you believe that and you're a parent and you see your child rejecting those covenants rejecting that eternal ceiling to the Time: 10:40 - 10:50 family you're basically seeing your child go away and you feel like you're losing them so unsurprisingly people leaving the mormon Time: 10:50 - 11:00 church creates huge upset within families like many other religions it's not just an insular cultural experience it is a deeply held doctrinal Time: 11:00 - 11:10 theological belief that if you leave the church there are major consequences luckily i had parents who Time: 11:10 - 11:20 by the time i told them that i was leaving the church were very open and loving and accepting of my decision certainly it was hurtful for them but they did not Time: 11:20 - 11:30 project that onto me in any way that made me feel ostracized unfortunately that is not the case for a lot of my friends a lot of other people who have left the church Time: 11:30 - 11:40 but even still with parents who were accepting and loving despite my decision i still had years of purging and Time: 11:40 - 11:50 processing to do something that continues to this day now four or five years later what i didn't realize is that i had internalized a lot of assumptions Time: 11:50 - 12:00 of shame and guilt and fear and judgment that i didn't even realize i had and for the years following leaving the Time: 12:00 - 12:10 church it was a process of slowly purging and peeling back and processing those things i went through the mr nice guy Time: 12:10 - 12:20 phase which is a very common thing for people who leave the lds church which is like i'm just leaving the church nice and peaceful i'm going to not be mean i'm not going to be spiteful towards the church because Time: 12:20 - 12:30 in the church when you're in it there's sort of this like like archetype of the spiteful angry anti- mormon who goes out and spreads Time: 12:30 - 12:40 lies about the church and they're just offended and angry and and i didn't want to be that person i don't want to be that archetype and so i tried to maintain very cordial relationships with everybody Time: 12:40 - 12:50 i tried to be super nice like you know the church was really great for me and and yet i just you know disagreed with it so i walked away i went through that phase for a couple of years Time: 12:50 - 13:00 but through therapy and through a lot of thinking about this i came to understand that i actually had some deep problems and anger towards the Time: 13:00 - 13:10 church and what it instilled in me i had anger and resentment towards a lot of the authority structures that made me feel unclean or dirty i had Time: 13:10 - 13:20 anger towards the systems that made me feel like obedience was the most important thing that submission to allah from god was much more important than self-expression and self- actualization Time: 13:20 - 13:30 i developed a resentment towards the church structure that has very homophobic and heteronormative Time: 13:30 - 13:40 and misogynistic structures that taught me to think in those terms a church that purports to love everybody but deeply condemns certain people because of who Time: 13:40 - 13:50 they love i'd rewire so much of that upon leaving and perhaps most frustratingly and maybe this is going to be hard to communicate the nuance to to someone Time: 13:50 - 14:00 who's not lds but i felt deep frustration at the church's claim to have a monopoly over the fullness of truth that the few Time: 14:00 - 14:10 million members are the only keepers of the real truth of what god wants today for us and that everyone else has truth too Time: 14:10 - 14:20 but through prophets and apostles and modern-day revelation the mormons are actually the ones who have the full picture they know what's going on i believed Time: 14:20 - 14:30 that they had the truth that was going to deliver me and my family to eternal bliss in celestial glory i believed that and i modeled my life Time: 14:30 - 14:40 around it deep into my adulthood and i feel resentment that i did that and that the stakes were so high for leaving for expressing myself and my qualms for Time: 14:40 - 14:50 this doctrine because after all if you question it you're questioning prophets people who are talking to god you can't do that it all left me very confused and Time: 14:50 - 15:00 required a lot of healing and processing in that is still going on and let me just be clear about something this isn't Time: 15:00 - 15:10 my millennial brain trying to reject authority structures and subvert old institutions like it's happening in a lot of religious contexts Time: 15:10 - 15:20 right now a lot of people are leaving religion i wasn't trying to get away from some disciplined structure my life is still a disciplined structure i still have a lot of the artifacts from my mormon Time: 15:20 - 15:30 upbringing what i was fleeing when i left the mormon church was a structure that i feel like put down who i really was made me cover it up in the name of a Time: 15:30 - 15:40 broader vision of what righteousness is and what jesus wants me to do it wasn't me it was harmful towards me Time: 15:40 - 15:50 and it was harmful towards others and the consequences were severe if you spoke up and you challenged the status quo the culture is not one of discourse and Time: 15:50 - 16:00 debate it's one of obedience obedience obedience obedience obedience is a hallmark belief and tenet of the lds experience Time: 16:00 - 16:10 and as a member you feel it leaving the church is painful socially mentally Time: 16:10 - 16:20 you experience a cost for doing so and if you're in that situation now which i know some of those watching are where you know that your family Time: 16:20 - 16:30 and your peers will think differently of you if you decide to leave just know that it's a lot better on the other side if you choose yourself Time: 16:30 - 16:40 and you choose your personal experience and your personal expression and you honor that as opposed to honoring the fear of obedience Time: 16:40 - 16:50 there's some years of pain and adjustment but there is a sense of freedom on the other side this is uncomfortable for me to say even right now i'm imagining Time: 16:50 - 17:00 whether it's family or friends who are still active believers in the church watching this i can feel that discomfort even now years later of what are they thinking of Time: 17:00 - 17:10 me making this video and and effectively talking to others who might be in the church and telling them to leave that that old archetype of the bitter Time: 17:10 - 17:20 ex-mormon who's polarizing and an extremist is is is ringing in my ears and yet day by day those voices and those old models Time: 17:20 - 17:30 they dissolve more and more and they become less loud and they become less part of my identity i for many years did identify as someone who used to be mormon and now i'm not Time: 17:30 - 17:40 but yet with time i'm slowly developing my own new identity that isn't pinned to my reactionary experience with the church but it's just Time: 17:40 - 17:50 pinned to who i am what i love i'm a father who loves my children i love to learn about the world and explore and explain things i love Time: 17:50 - 18:00 film i love animation i love moss i love cooking i love reading stories to my boys and teaching them about the world i love traveling i love Time: 18:00 - comments.text:
with, their misuse of the Bible, to twist to their own needs as desired. They also believed their church was
the only people that were going to Heaven. I left when I  was 15, and was ex-communicated, and officially
purged, from my entire family and everything I had ever known. I was told I was full of demons and I was
going straight to hell, by my mom.
It was terrifying. I was so sheltered and knew absolutely nothing about the "real world". I made lots of
mistakes, but my Lord had never forsaken me, and protected me from more than I am probably aware.
I'm 47 now, and I have a " friendship" with my family, but after being separated for so many years, we are
strangers. I have a family of my own, and can't EVER imagine doing that to my child at 15. It hurts my heart
to this day, but I've forgiven, just as the Lord forgave me.

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: A couple of years ago, I dated a guy who was still active in the Mormon church- I'm also a guy, so you

comments.text:
know how that sounds. He was out to his family and they accepted him, but didn't know he was dating
other men (if they knew, they would make him resign). He did a mission and worked in his church's
council, and although he knew he would have to leave the church if he wanted to be open about loving me,
he still devoutly believed it. He was so convicted that his beliefs were the only way, and I saw the
consequences he'd face if he left... those of which he never explicitly mentioned. I loved him so much, but
I had to let him go because I couldn't handle the thought of me essentially taking his whole world away
from him... I feared he'd resent me. It's so hard to love someone, but never truly have them. I don't know
where he is today, but I hope he's safe, happy, and okay.

comments.timestamp: Fun fact: Ivan the Terrible's actual nickname doesn't actually mean "terrible". The modern English meaning

comments.text:
of the word shifted towards "horrible, awful", but the original Russian nickname Грозный (Grozny) actually
means "formidable, dangerous, powerful". Oh and if you like Game of Thrones, read his biography. You'll
get: wars, conspiracy, coups, all sorts of dirty politics and much more! Did you know a rival noble clan
poisoned his first wife Anastasia and her death caused a collapse in his mental health that made him
unhinged? And how all of it was part of a power play by the aristocrats to take power from Ivan, and how
he viciously retaliated by essentially wiping the old clans who posed a potential threat out? And the
Oprichnina? History is fascinating

date line in between.

Russian island.

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: A couple of interesting facts about 11 time zones:

comments.text:
- When Russia celebrates New Years, news anchors congratulate some big city hourly. It's like a
countdown - the more cities are mentioned, the closer the holiday.
- Often all sorts of television programs are leaked onto the Internet, because they are first shown in the Far
East, and they will reach Moscow in about 10 hours. Therefore, for example, people from Moscow can
always find the President's New Year messages on the Internet long before the New Year.
- Sometimes what the government doesn't like is accidentally shown on television in the Far East. These
things are being cut out of programs while they trudge to Moscow. It's always fun to talk about things like
that.

comments.timestamp: Just a note; fast attack subs are also called Hunter-killer subs and are made for sinking other submarines

comments.text:
or surface vessels as well as protecting friendly ballistic missile subs and surface vessels. Some modern
fast attack subs also carry the capability of launching cruise missiles as well as advanced surveillance
equipment which allows them to fill a multi role niche. The ballistic missile subs also have advanced
surveillance equipment but their main purpose is to be ready on station to fire missiles if needed. At least
that’s my understanding of it.

comments.timestamp: Wanna hear something that utterly ups the terrifying nature of nuclear submarines?

comments.text:
I was cleaning out my ex’s car some years ago, and found some documents from her ex, who had served
on an ICBM submarine in the US navy. One mentioned a dishonorable discharge from his military service. I
was curious as to how he had managed to get a dishonorable discharge, so i asked. Her answer changed
the way i view the world forever. Homeboy had been selling his fellow sailors LSD, while on active duty.
I mean, i thought that scene from Apocalypse Now was wild, but hearing this story was mind blowing.
People with their fingers on the doomsday button, tripping balls on acid in a compressed metal tube with
no windows. True story.
comments.author: Unknown

sub and its related politics, thanks to Clancy's close relationships with the Navy.

game of the same name was wildly enjoyable to play as a kid in the 1980s. 😊

something other than beating up our neighbors.

comments.timestamp: Countries keep the geometry of the propellers of their submarines top secret because they generate the

comments.text:
majority of the noise. Somebody detecting that noise could interpret various parameters if they also know
the diameter, number of blades, blade shape, direction of the prop. Every unique prop is like a signature for
the submarine and can be catalogued by opposing intelligences to determine the mission capabilities of
whichever enemy vessel they encounter.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Wow, this video is truly amazing! I was completely engrossed for the entire 30 minutes. The information

comments.text:
on submarines and their capabilities was so informative and eye-opening. I had no idea that they were
capable of so much. The presentation was top-notch, and the video production was of high quality. In this
age of short attention spans, it's refreshing to see a video that can hold my interest for such a long time.
Keep up the great work!
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: You really should cover the story of Eugene Fluckey who wrote about his experience of the second world

comments.text:
war in the Pacific being a skipper of the USS Barb (the book - Thunder Below - is extraordinary). He sunk
17 ships including an aircraft carrier, and literally destroyed a train. Oh and he revolutionized submarine
warfare by launching rockets from his surfaced sub.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: It's incredible we getting this top tier journalism for free. You and your amazing team have my full support,

comments.text: thanks for the great vid.
comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Humanity in a nutshell: wasting all the resources to fight over resources.

videos.title: Why Saudi Arabia is Building a $1 Trillion City in the Desert - I've been sleeping every night in the desert.

comments.text:
and have now gone back two more times in the past year. The people and country were not at all what I
expected. My understanding of the country had come from news reports and movies. The reality is a
beautiful landscape and friendly, welcoming people who I've come to be friends with. I recommend
anyone really wanting to understand the Middle East visit Saudi Arabia and in particular visit AlUla, which
is as breathtaking as this video.

comments.timestamp: This didn’t really explain why it’s like this. Diner breakfast came from our farming days. Most of America

comments.text:
used to be a farm. We ate foods from the farm that were incredibly calorie dense in order to maintain the
energy to do farm work. Cereal breakfast came from the 40s and 50s. No longer on farms, but still lacking
a lot in transportation in our gigantic country, we had basically no fresh food. Hence everything came in a
can or a box (you know all those weird preserved food recipes from the 50s) We just continued these two
traditions.

comments.author: Unknown
comments.timestamp: Breakfast loaded with carbs has been thought to be a product of past necessity and only a vague

comments.text:
understanding of how the human body works. America's breakfasts started getting sweeter around the
industrial revolution and was emphasized around WW2, playing around the idea that high carb breakfasts
will keep you energized for the day. It mostly took place because of America's high abundance of sugar at
the time while other resources were either low or being funneled towards other efforts such as war. After
the war, the cereal industry started mass-producing sugar-coated cereals and marketing towards children
in order to make use of some of the over-stocked sugar supplies, thus a breakfast staple weaseled its way
into America's pantries across the country.
What the video neglects to tell us is that pancakes have always been thought to be a breakfast item,
believed to be first invented around 1100AD. America started using the term "pancakes" in the 1870s to
describe their "flapjacks", and syrup only became part of the toppings list around the 1880s. The
traditional American breakfast
